FacilityName: Trident Seafoods Corporation - False Pass Seafoods

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
False Pass Seafoods is committed to the safety of those working in our facility, as well as the safety of the community where we work and live. The plant has a refrigeration system that uses anhydrous ammonia to freeze fish and seafood products. The ammonia inventory is more than 10,000 pounds, and in accordance with the OSHA and EPA requirements, we have developed a Process Safety Management and a Risk Management Program. There is a management system describing overall responsibility for the program and there is a person responsible for each element of the PSM/RM program. 



The plant performed an initial Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) with employees to assist in making decisions for improving safety and reducing the consequences of unwanted or unplanned releases. In addition, at least every 5 years this process hazard analysis will be reviewed and updated. Every 3 years a third-party compliance audit will be conducted to review the PSM / RMP program elements for compliance with the regulation. 



The refrigeration facility has been constructed following local, state and industry code requirements

and guidelines. In addition, recognized and generally accepted good engineering practices (REGAGEP) have been adopted through the application of standards provided by the International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration (IIAR). 



A Hazard Assessment has been completed which considers a worst-case ammonia release

scenario as well as several alternate or more likely to occur accidents. This study has been used to

develop the facility emergency action plan. There have been no accidents, injuries, or property damage resulting from an ammonia release in the last 5 years.



In the event of an ammonia release, the facility Emergency Action Plan would be implemented. The

facility first responders will provide proper measures to safely evacuate plant personnel to prearranged

muster areas. Appropriate community notification will be made for either emergency evacuation or p

ossible "shelter in place" instructions.



Facility personnel are provided personal protective equipment for their level of involvement and are HAZWOPER trained for emergency response on a yearly basis. There are emergency plant evacuation drills practiced seasonally to ensure that employees will know what to do and where to go in the event of any emergency.
